description: This series explores the practical application of DNS, the Domain Naming System.  We demonstrate using DNS records to support websites, mail servers, and other services.  Other topics addressed include DNS security, replication, and popular server software including BIND and Microsoft Windows DNS.
name: DNS
subtitle: Maintaining the Domain Name System

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don discuss how to obtain information from a DNS server with the NSLookup command. They explain the different modes interactive and non-interactive that an administrator can use and what these modes are used for.
episodes.title: nslookup
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:01.352
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.352 --> 00:00:07.871
I'm your host, Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.871 --> 00:00:08.381
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.381 --> 00:00:12.016
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.016 --> 00:00:14.906
>> Welcome back to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.906 --> 00:00:18.920
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and today, we've
got a really good subject coming at you.

7
00:00:18.920 --> 00:00:22.904
We're gonna be talking about one of the
most important services on the Internet

8
00:00:22.904 --> 00:00:25.233
that really makes us get
around the Internet.

9
00:00:25.233 --> 00:00:28.216
And joining me in the studios today for
that topic is none other than Mr.

10
00:00:28.216 --> 00:00:28.730
Don Pezet.

11
00:00:28.730 --> 00:00:29.740
Don, how are you doing sir?

12
00:00:29.740 --> 00:00:30.740
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

13
00:00:30.740 --> 00:00:32.272
Ready to dive right back into DNS.

14
00:00:32.272 --> 00:00:35.736
In this episode, we're moving on
with our command line utilities,

15
00:00:35.736 --> 00:00:38.076
some of our utilities
that we can use with DNS.

16
00:00:38.076 --> 00:00:40.843
And in this particular episode,
we're gonna look at nslookup,

17
00:00:40.843 --> 00:00:44.164
which is probably one of the most useful
command line utilities when it comes to

18
00:00:44.164 --> 00:00:45.540
working with DNS.

19
00:00:45.540 --> 00:00:47.160
Anytime you're doing
configuration changes,

20
00:00:47.160 --> 00:00:49.790
anytime you're putting entries in, we
need to be able to verify that they work.

21
00:00:49.790 --> 00:00:53.010
You need to be able to test to make
sure that our names are resolving, and

22
00:00:53.010 --> 00:00:54.800
that's where nslookup comes in.

23
00:00:54.800 --> 00:00:58.010
So, just a real brief
synopsis on nslookup.

24
00:00:58.010 --> 00:01:00.552
The name stands for name server lookup.

25
00:01:00.552 --> 00:01:03.895
Just a command line utility that we can
reach out and it talks to DNS servers, so

26
00:01:03.895 --> 00:01:06.986
that we can recreate the queries that
all of our other servers are doing in

27
00:01:06.986 --> 00:01:08.310
the background.

28
00:01:08.310 --> 00:01:13.630
Nice thing about nslookup, it's present
on Windows, Linux, Unix, MacOS.

29
00:01:13.630 --> 00:01:16.876
Pretty much every system these
days has nslookup baked in.

30
00:01:16.876 --> 00:01:17.903
And to be honest with you,

31
00:01:17.903 --> 00:01:21.360
I can't remember the last time that I
encountered a system that didn't have it.

32
00:01:21.360 --> 00:01:24.590
There's some of those really stripped
down Linux distros that might not have it

33
00:01:24.590 --> 00:01:28.360
installed by default, but you can throw it
right on there pretty easily through one

34
00:01:28.360 --> 00:01:30.990
of the repositories and have access to it.

35
00:01:30.990 --> 00:01:35.270
The other nice thing about nslookup
is the command line syntax

36
00:01:35.270 --> 00:01:37.890
is pretty much identical between
all the operating systems.

37
00:01:37.890 --> 00:01:41.410
So, if you know how to use it on Windows,
then, you know how to use it on a Mac.

38
00:01:41.410 --> 00:01:43.780
And if you know how to use it on a Mac,
you know how to use it on Unix and Linux.

39
00:01:43.780 --> 00:01:47.490
So, it's all kinda tied together and
that makes this one really robust.

40
00:01:47.490 --> 00:01:50.425
So, that's what we're gonna take
a look at right here in this episode.

41
00:01:50.425 --> 00:01:52.062
All right, so, enough talking about it.

42
00:01:52.062 --> 00:01:54.550
All right, let's get in here and
take a look and see it.

43
00:01:54.550 --> 00:01:57.900
You know you have nslookup, well,
it's actually pretty easy to see.

44
00:01:57.900 --> 00:02:00.640
We know we have it in pretty much
every operating systems out there.

45
00:02:00.640 --> 00:02:03.320
You can just run it and see.

46
00:02:03.320 --> 00:02:06.270
If you don't have it for some reason,
which really would just be like kind of

47
00:02:06.270 --> 00:02:09.765
some Linux distributions that
might not have it, most of us,

48
00:02:09.765 --> 00:02:11.940
we should have this, no big deal, right?

49
00:02:11.940 --> 00:02:15.550
But if you just run it, what you should
see is basically what I got right here.

50
00:02:15.550 --> 00:02:19.030
It's gonna jump in and you should end up
with a greater than prompt like that,

51
00:02:19.030 --> 00:02:19.970
all right?

52
00:02:19.970 --> 00:02:24.780
What I just did is I entered what's called
the interactive command line for nslookup.

53
00:02:24.780 --> 00:02:29.070
So, once I'm in here, I'm technically
still in the nslookup utility.

54
00:02:29.070 --> 00:02:30.920
And now,
I can start running commands against it,

55
00:02:30.920 --> 00:02:33.570
as many commands as I want, all right.

56
00:02:33.570 --> 00:02:36.320
But for most of us, we're not gonna
go with the interactive mode.

57
00:02:36.320 --> 00:02:38.379
We're going to stick with
the non-interactive mode,

58
00:02:38.379 --> 00:02:41.375
where we run a command, it does what we
ask it to do, and then it's done, right?

59
00:02:41.375 --> 00:02:43.372
It just gets in, gets out,
and in, that's it.

60
00:02:43.372 --> 00:02:45.896
So, let me exit out of that,
back to my prompt.

61
00:02:45.896 --> 00:02:49.830
And the non-interactive mode
is the most straight forward.

62
00:02:49.830 --> 00:02:51.120
It is the one I use most of the time.

63
00:02:51.120 --> 00:02:53.540
We're just trying to do something
like simple name resolution.

64
00:02:53.540 --> 00:02:58.900
So, if I wanna find out what the IP
address of the ITProTV website is, right?

65
00:02:58.900 --> 00:03:05.134
What I can do is I can jump in here and
I can just say, nslookup itpro.tv.

66
00:03:05.134 --> 00:03:09.244
And it's gonna reach out to that DNS
server and it's gonna do a lookout, okay.

67
00:03:09.244 --> 00:03:13.678
Now, when it did the lookup, notice I
got this DNS request timed out, right?

68
00:03:13.678 --> 00:03:15.003
Timeout was 2 seconds.

69
00:03:15.003 --> 00:03:16.190
What does that mean?

70
00:03:16.190 --> 00:03:20.930
Well, whatever my main DNS
server is wasn't answering.

71
00:03:20.930 --> 00:03:23.070
And so,
it skipped forward to the next one, right?

72
00:03:23.070 --> 00:03:25.784
I can see that progression
that just happened and

73
00:03:25.784 --> 00:03:29.036
it moved forward to a Google server,
to 8.8.8.8.

74
00:03:29.036 --> 00:03:30.680
Right, so, I hit that one and
that one was fine.

75
00:03:30.680 --> 00:03:33.120
And then,
I was able to resolve my address.

76
00:03:33.120 --> 00:03:37.160
So, I get some feedback about that
query process and what happened.

77
00:03:37.160 --> 00:03:39.830
But it's not terribly detailed, right?

78
00:03:39.830 --> 00:03:42.830
It didn't tell me what it timed out on.

79
00:03:42.830 --> 00:03:45.134
So, what was my primary DNS server?

80
00:03:45.134 --> 00:03:46.040
I don't know.

81
00:03:46.040 --> 00:03:48.856
It also says here that it's
a non-authoritative answer.

82
00:03:48.856 --> 00:03:50.340
Now, remember, with non-authoritative,

83
00:03:50.340 --> 00:03:54.830
that means the server that I asked
didn't actually have the answer for me.

84
00:03:54.830 --> 00:03:57.820
It had to do a recursive lookup
against some other server.

85
00:03:57.820 --> 00:04:02.380
And so, it reached out and talked to other
servers and hid all that from me and

86
00:04:02.380 --> 00:04:03.590
gave me this answer.

87
00:04:03.590 --> 00:04:07.750
When we use the non-interactive mode, you
get a really simplified output like this.

88
00:04:07.750 --> 00:04:11.580
If we want really detailed output
where we see all the different steps,

89
00:04:11.580 --> 00:04:13.880
that's where the interactive
mode comes in.

90
00:04:13.880 --> 00:04:15.830
So, that's a real simple
lookup right there.

91
00:04:15.830 --> 00:04:20.810
You provided a domain name or a host name,
and it gives you back an IP address.

92
00:04:20.810 --> 00:04:24.270
There's really only one other thing we can
do here from the non-interactive mode.

93
00:04:24.270 --> 00:04:27.400
Notice how I get the server that
I did a lookup against, right?

94
00:04:27.400 --> 00:04:29.500
I can override that server.

95
00:04:29.500 --> 00:04:33.107
I can say instead of looking
up against 8.8.8.8, maybe,

96
00:04:33.107 --> 00:04:36.069
I wanna lookup against 4.2.2.1, all right?

97
00:04:36.069 --> 00:04:39.330
And when we do that,
we're overriding the server.

98
00:04:39.330 --> 00:04:40.820
Now, why would we wanna do that?

99
00:04:40.820 --> 00:04:43.803
Well, have you ever made
a change to a public DNS record?

100
00:04:43.803 --> 00:04:46.326
So, if you go on GoDaddy or
Hover or Register,

101
00:04:46.326 --> 00:04:49.262
or whatever it is that you
purchase your domain name.

102
00:04:49.262 --> 00:04:52.040
You log in to the website and
you make a change to an A record.

103
00:04:52.040 --> 00:04:55.420
The real message it'll say, this could
take up to 48 hours to take effect.

104
00:04:56.420 --> 00:04:57.630
But what does that mean?

105
00:04:57.630 --> 00:04:59.330
In computers, what takes 48 hours?

106
00:04:59.330 --> 00:05:02.923
Well, your change actually takes effect
immediately, right the moment you do it.

107
00:05:02.923 --> 00:05:07.101
But people around the world will cache
your DNS record and they can cache it for

108
00:05:07.101 --> 00:05:08.070
up to 48 hours.

109
00:05:08.070 --> 00:05:09.140
So, that's why they warn you about that.

110
00:05:09.140 --> 00:05:11.570
Hey, it can take up to two days for
everybody to purge their cache and

111
00:05:11.570 --> 00:05:13.180
learn your new address.

112
00:05:13.180 --> 00:05:15.950
So, if you ever wanna see how
far you've propagated out,

113
00:05:15.950 --> 00:05:17.670
you might do what I just did.

114
00:05:17.670 --> 00:05:19.550
Do a lookup against Google server.

115
00:05:19.550 --> 00:05:21.360
Do a lookup against Level Three server.

116
00:05:21.360 --> 00:05:23.948
Do a lookup against your ISP,
other people's ISPs and

117
00:05:23.948 --> 00:05:27.951
see whether they've received the change
already or not, and you'd be surprised.

118
00:05:27.951 --> 00:05:31.980
It's a rare change that takes more than
like an hour to propagate out these days.

119
00:05:31.980 --> 00:05:36.360
>> Don, now, when you said override,
is that taking the interface assigned

120
00:05:36.360 --> 00:05:38.670
DNS server and saying,
hey we're not gonna use this.

121
00:05:38.670 --> 00:05:41.250
We're gonna use the IP address of
what you've just put there at the end

122
00:05:41.250 --> 00:05:42.065
of nslookup?

123
00:05:42.065 --> 00:05:43.900
>> Yeah, on Windows,

124
00:05:43.900 --> 00:05:46.740
it's whatever DNS server you have
assigned to your network adapter.

125
00:05:46.740 --> 00:05:48.451
If you're running Mac or Linux,

126
00:05:48.451 --> 00:05:51.517
it's whatever DNS servers
are in your resolve.com file.

127
00:05:51.517 --> 00:05:53.392
So, that's what a stuff's defined, and

128
00:05:53.392 --> 00:05:56.130
that's all nslookup does is
it looks up those things.

129
00:05:56.130 --> 00:05:58.950
I guess, important thing to mention
here is that some operating

130
00:05:58.950 --> 00:06:01.245
systems have a DNS cache built in to them,
right?

131
00:06:01.245 --> 00:06:05.844
Windows has it, it's super annoying,
where [LAUGH] Windows will do a lookup and

132
00:06:05.844 --> 00:06:07.230
it will cache a record.

133
00:06:07.230 --> 00:06:09.650
And then,
when you go to browse that webpage again,

134
00:06:09.650 --> 00:06:11.804
it doesn't actually go
out to the DNS server.

135
00:06:11.804 --> 00:06:13.151
It just uses its own cache, right?

136
00:06:13.151 --> 00:06:15.185
This is where the whole
40-hour thing comes in.

137
00:06:15.185 --> 00:06:17.915
So, if we wanna override that,
well, in Windows,

138
00:06:17.915 --> 00:06:19.835
some of you guys might be
familiar with the command.

139
00:06:19.835 --> 00:06:20.735
Let me show you.

140
00:06:20.735 --> 00:06:26.940
It's ipconfig /flushdns and
that will wipe your DNS cache, right?

141
00:06:26.940 --> 00:06:31.050
Well, nslookup doesn't use
the DNS cache in Windows.

142
00:06:31.050 --> 00:06:32.950
So, it's actually bypassing that cache.

143
00:06:32.950 --> 00:06:37.950
Now, the reason I bring that up is
you might fire up a web browser, and

144
00:06:37.950 --> 00:06:40.160
try and go to web page,
and you can't get there.

145
00:06:40.160 --> 00:06:44.170
And you drop to a command prompt and
use nslookup, but it show us the right IP.

146
00:06:44.170 --> 00:06:48.578
And the problem is that Chrome,
Firefox, Internet Explorer,

147
00:06:48.578 --> 00:06:52.832
whatever, might be using the DNS cache and
NSlookup isn't.

148
00:06:52.832 --> 00:06:54.351
And so, they have two different records.

149
00:06:54.351 --> 00:06:56.232
That's where you might have
to flush the cache here.

150
00:06:56.232 --> 00:06:59.160
But nslookup does not use
the DNS cache on your system.

151
00:06:59.160 --> 00:07:01.680
>> So, if you want just a quick
answer from a DNS server,

152
00:07:01.680 --> 00:07:05.000
you can just use nslookup, you said,
in the non-interactive mode.

153
00:07:05.000 --> 00:07:07.150
Now, you mentioned that term
interactive mode, you said,

154
00:07:07.150 --> 00:07:08.460
that's where the actions at.

155
00:07:08.460 --> 00:07:09.890
Tell us a little bit about that, Don.

156
00:07:09.890 --> 00:07:12.940
>> All right, so,
pretty limited options here, right?

157
00:07:12.940 --> 00:07:16.150
I can provide a host name or DNS name and
I can override the server, and

158
00:07:16.150 --> 00:07:17.590
that's really about it.

159
00:07:17.590 --> 00:07:20.500
But if we get into the interactive mode,
there are a ton

160
00:07:20.500 --> 00:07:23.610
of options that we can jump in there and
start to manipulate it and change.

161
00:07:23.610 --> 00:07:27.510
So, if I just run nslookup by itself,
that's gonna take me

162
00:07:27.510 --> 00:07:30.800
into that interactive prompt and
I'll get my DNS timed out again.

163
00:07:30.800 --> 00:07:32.990
[LAUGH] So
i'll just switch over to the other server.

164
00:07:32.990 --> 00:07:37.090
So, anyhow, once I'm in there, now, I
could start to change the way things work.

165
00:07:37.090 --> 00:07:41.900
If you just do a question mark, you'll get
a list of all the different commands and

166
00:07:41.900 --> 00:07:43.570
things that we can put in there.

167
00:07:43.570 --> 00:07:47.590
And right off the bat, you'll notice
that you can do a lookup for a name or

168
00:07:47.590 --> 00:07:49.180
a host name just by typing it in.

169
00:07:49.180 --> 00:07:50.322
So, I just type in whatever that name is.

170
00:07:50.322 --> 00:07:52.580
Type in ITProTV and it will resolve it.

171
00:07:52.580 --> 00:07:55.723
But then, there's all these
set options that we can do.

172
00:07:55.723 --> 00:07:58.814
To override the way that
things are working.

173
00:07:58.814 --> 00:08:03.150
And way down here we'll see where
we can set the server also.

174
00:08:03.150 --> 00:08:07.220
So earlier I was overriding
the server from the command line.

175
00:08:07.220 --> 00:08:11.237
From here, anytime I do a look up,
right now it's using 8.8.8.8, right?

176
00:08:11.237 --> 00:08:16.390
So if I do a look up for
itpro.tv It's using 8.8.8.8.

177
00:08:16.390 --> 00:08:20.824
But if I do server 4.2.2.1, right?

178
00:08:20.824 --> 00:08:23.220
Now it's changing my resolver.

179
00:08:23.220 --> 00:08:25.610
I'm now changed over to 4.2.2.1,

180
00:08:25.610 --> 00:08:29.850
and every look up I do from here on out,
it's gonna do against that resolver.

181
00:08:29.850 --> 00:08:32.530
So if I look up itpro.tv.

182
00:08:32.530 --> 00:08:35.256
There we go, it ran it, and
it ran it against 4.2.2.1 and

183
00:08:35.256 --> 00:08:36.375
I didn't have to tell it.

184
00:08:36.375 --> 00:08:42.910
And then I could jump in and say cnn.com,
and there it goes, again off of 4.2.2.1.

185
00:08:42.910 --> 00:08:48.359
If I do a server, let's see 8.8.

186
00:08:48.359 --> 00:08:49.917
What's the other one, 8.8.4.4?

187
00:08:49.917 --> 00:08:51.935
>> 4.4
>> That's it, the other Google one.

188
00:08:51.935 --> 00:08:53.790
There we are,
I'll switch to the other Google one.

189
00:08:53.790 --> 00:08:56.681
And now I can run that lookup for
itpro.tv, and

190
00:08:56.681 --> 00:08:58.690
there it goes doing that lookup.

191
00:08:58.690 --> 00:09:01.570
And it didn't make me have to
provide the server every time.

192
00:09:01.570 --> 00:09:03.970
>> Now Don, with all those options,
who are the demographic?

193
00:09:03.970 --> 00:09:08.714
Who would really be using this with all
those, all that flexibility and power?

194
00:09:08.714 --> 00:09:12.634
>> All right, so an end user or
a Help Desk technician might use the basic

195
00:09:12.634 --> 00:09:17.730
NsLookup just to test DNS resolution or
to find out the IP of a host, all right?

196
00:09:17.730 --> 00:09:21.820
But beyond that,
it's really gonna be DNS administrators.

197
00:09:21.820 --> 00:09:25.840
If you're administering a DNS server,
NS lookup has some incredible features in

198
00:09:25.840 --> 00:09:28.064
it that will let us
troubleshoot the server.

199
00:09:28.064 --> 00:09:29.420
Let me just give you an example.

200
00:09:29.420 --> 00:09:33.260
So there are some denial of service
attacks that can be pulled off against DNS

201
00:09:33.260 --> 00:09:35.560
servers using TCP.

202
00:09:35.560 --> 00:09:39.170
And so you might decide to block TCP and
only allow UDP

203
00:09:39.170 --> 00:09:41.800
lookups against your server, or vice
versa, you might want to go the other way.

204
00:09:41.800 --> 00:09:45.587
So maybe you configure your server to only
answer on UDP, or only answer on TCP.

205
00:09:45.587 --> 00:09:47.380
How do you test that?

206
00:09:47.380 --> 00:09:50.300
Well, in NS lookup, let me just
do that question mark again, or

207
00:09:50.300 --> 00:09:51.950
actually you can do,
well there's a few ways.

208
00:09:51.950 --> 00:09:52.559
I'll do the question mark.

209
00:09:53.850 --> 00:09:57.010
If you look,
there's all these set OPTIONs in here.

210
00:09:57.010 --> 00:09:59.940
And if you look at the set OPTIONs,
and kinda look down at the list,

211
00:09:59.940 --> 00:10:03.750
you'll see where you can override
all sorts of different things.

212
00:10:03.750 --> 00:10:07.920
How you do the transfer, the class, the
type of query, the timeout, the domain,

213
00:10:07.920 --> 00:10:09.300
the search list.

214
00:10:09.300 --> 00:10:12.400
And just all sorts of really
interesting things here to tweak.

215
00:10:12.400 --> 00:10:15.520
And so, you can see how you're
talking to that server.

216
00:10:15.520 --> 00:10:18.820
One of my favorite options
is this debug option.

217
00:10:18.820 --> 00:10:24.030
The debug option gives you a ton of
output about that lookup, right?

218
00:10:24.030 --> 00:10:26.040
Let me show you that in action.

219
00:10:26.040 --> 00:10:28.530
I'm gonna do a lookup for itpro.tv.

220
00:10:28.530 --> 00:10:31.540
Very simple, I get the server that
I do the look up against, and

221
00:10:31.540 --> 00:10:36.030
then I see the host name and the IP
address that I got back, and that's it.

222
00:10:36.030 --> 00:10:39.552
It was non-authoritative so I know other
stuff happened in the background, but

223
00:10:39.552 --> 00:10:41.060
I don't see it, all right?

224
00:10:41.060 --> 00:10:42.800
Let me just clear a little bit of this.

225
00:10:42.800 --> 00:10:47.447
And what I'm gonna do now,
is I'm gonna say, set debug, all right?

226
00:10:47.447 --> 00:10:49.786
Set debug, that turns on the debug mode.

227
00:10:49.786 --> 00:10:53.137
And now I'm going to get
a very verbose output.

228
00:10:53.137 --> 00:10:59.491
When I do a look up for itpro.tv,
I get a lot more information.

229
00:10:59.491 --> 00:11:01.090
Look at all this, right?

230
00:11:01.090 --> 00:11:04.268
I do see that I reached out
to google server 8.8.4.4,

231
00:11:04.268 --> 00:11:06.961
and then here's my answer that came back,
right?

232
00:11:06.961 --> 00:11:08.240
I got a header.

233
00:11:08.240 --> 00:11:09.978
I got a query, is what I performed.

234
00:11:09.978 --> 00:11:11.630
I got no error on the query.

235
00:11:11.630 --> 00:11:13.065
Sometimes you can have
a malformed query and

236
00:11:13.065 --> 00:11:15.270
it'll show up if there
was an error right there.

237
00:11:15.270 --> 00:11:16.800
I can see there was a response.

238
00:11:16.800 --> 00:11:19.720
We wanted recursion, and
recursion was available.

239
00:11:19.720 --> 00:11:22.870
This server didn't have the answer so
it's gonna have to go somewhere else.

240
00:11:22.870 --> 00:11:24.415
I see I sent one question.

241
00:11:24.415 --> 00:11:25.630
I got one answer.

242
00:11:25.630 --> 00:11:30.140
And I guess this is kind of off my
screen here, but authority record 0.

243
00:11:30.140 --> 00:11:33.835
We didn't have the record for it,
we had to go somewhere else, right?

244
00:11:33.835 --> 00:11:36.441
And then,
here's the question that I asked, and

245
00:11:36.441 --> 00:11:40.170
here's the answer that I got with a ttl,
and how long it took.

246
00:11:40.170 --> 00:11:45.320
So it's laying all that out for
me, and kinda putting it in here.

247
00:11:45.320 --> 00:11:48.659
And as I look at it, if you see a little
bit here as far as like a four A record,

248
00:11:48.659 --> 00:11:49.723
which should be IPv6.

249
00:11:49.723 --> 00:11:52.600
We actually don't have one,
and so this came back empty.

250
00:11:52.600 --> 00:11:57.472
But it looks like I did IPv4,
as well as an IPv6 look up for

251
00:11:57.472 --> 00:11:59.864
that host, for itpro.tv.

252
00:11:59.864 --> 00:12:02.550
And that's cuz I'm on Windows,
not every operating system does that.

253
00:12:02.550 --> 00:12:05.400
>> Now Don, right there in that last bit
of output you've talked about in other

254
00:12:05.400 --> 00:12:06.910
episodes, about the start of authority.

255
00:12:06.910 --> 00:12:07.630
Is that what we're seeing,

256
00:12:07.630 --> 00:12:11.640
the authoritative information for
this response?

257
00:12:11.640 --> 00:12:14.940
>> Absolutely, so ITPro.TV,
if I remember right,

258
00:12:14.940 --> 00:12:18.380
that domain is registered with
a registrar called Hover.com.

259
00:12:18.380 --> 00:12:22.030
And so if I were to do a lookup
against Hover's DNS servers,

260
00:12:22.030 --> 00:12:24.890
then I would get
an authoritative response on it.

261
00:12:24.890 --> 00:12:27.790
But if I ask any other
DNS server on the planet,

262
00:12:27.790 --> 00:12:29.730
it's not gonna be authoritative, right?

263
00:12:29.730 --> 00:12:33.560
It's going to have to send that
query up through the tuple,

264
00:12:33.560 --> 00:12:34.398
the domain chain, right?

265
00:12:34.398 --> 00:12:35.890
So it's gotta start at a root hint server,

266
00:12:35.890 --> 00:12:38.510
and it's gotta find the servers for
.TV, right?

267
00:12:38.510 --> 00:12:42.230
TV's a country code, so it's gotta go and
find that country code and

268
00:12:42.230 --> 00:12:43.600
who manages that.

269
00:12:43.600 --> 00:12:47.950
And once it finds that, then it can find
where the actual SOA for ITPro.tv is,

270
00:12:47.950 --> 00:12:50.620
and then it can go there to get
the authoritative answer, and

271
00:12:50.620 --> 00:12:51.470
pass that back over to me.

272
00:12:51.470 --> 00:12:54.830
So there's gonna be at least three more
lookups that are kind of on the back-end

273
00:12:54.830 --> 00:12:57.490
of this query that I sent,
assuming it's not cached.

274
00:12:57.490 --> 00:13:00.130
It could already be in the DNS cache for
Google, and they'll respond.

275
00:13:00.130 --> 00:13:01.630
That's the advantage of
using Google servers,

276
00:13:01.630 --> 00:13:03.480
is that they've cached
darn near everything.

277
00:13:03.480 --> 00:13:06.440
So you can get those
responses back really quick.

278
00:13:06.440 --> 00:13:09.220
All right, so that's debug.

279
00:13:09.220 --> 00:13:12.480
With the debug option we saw
a lot of good output but

280
00:13:12.480 --> 00:13:15.850
there are a lot of things that
you don't necessarily see, and

281
00:13:15.850 --> 00:13:19.630
we'll see other utilities later on
that will let us see even more.

282
00:13:19.630 --> 00:13:23.950
But there's another thing that I find
kind of useful in the Windows world.

283
00:13:23.950 --> 00:13:27.020
Windows, if you have a Windows
machine joined to a domain,

284
00:13:27.020 --> 00:13:29.360
you'll have a default suffix list.

285
00:13:29.360 --> 00:13:30.500
So when you do a search for

286
00:13:30.500 --> 00:13:35.860
a single name, it will append onto
the end of it what your search list is.

287
00:13:35.860 --> 00:13:39.465
So for example,
if I have a domain called domain.net.

288
00:13:39.465 --> 00:13:42.237
And I do a lookup for ITPro.tv,

289
00:13:42.237 --> 00:13:48.106
the lookup might actually get
formed as ITPro.tv.domain.net.

290
00:13:48.106 --> 00:13:50.595
It sticks it on the end,
which is kind of annoying.

291
00:13:50.595 --> 00:13:54.325
And so you'll notice in my set options
that we can do this enabling and

292
00:13:54.325 --> 00:13:55.845
disabling of the search, right?

293
00:13:55.845 --> 00:13:56.955
That's the suffix list.

294
00:13:56.955 --> 00:13:59.175
And do we wanna search this list or not?

295
00:13:59.175 --> 00:14:01.700
Do I just wanna search for what I typed?

296
00:14:01.700 --> 00:14:04.235
Or do we wanna add the search
list to the end, right?

297
00:14:04.235 --> 00:14:06.839
You can do the same thing with recursion.

298
00:14:06.839 --> 00:14:08.880
So maybe I don't want to do recursion.

299
00:14:08.880 --> 00:14:12.920
Either this server is gonna have
the answer I want, or they're not.

300
00:14:12.920 --> 00:14:14.120
Now by default that's on.

301
00:14:14.120 --> 00:14:16.320
We ask for recursive quarries, right?

302
00:14:16.320 --> 00:14:19.390
So set recurs is the default.

303
00:14:19.390 --> 00:14:23.920
So me entering that in is
gonna have no effect, right?

304
00:14:23.920 --> 00:14:29.770
But if I do set norecurs, now I'm
disabling recursive queries, right?

305
00:14:29.770 --> 00:14:34.128
And if I do a look up against Google for
example, my debug is still on.

306
00:14:34.128 --> 00:14:35.980
I'm gonna do a set nodebug.

307
00:14:37.070 --> 00:14:40.278
All these set commands, to turn them on,
you do set and the name of the command.

308
00:14:40.278 --> 00:14:43.490
To turn them off you do set, and
then no followed by the command.

309
00:14:43.490 --> 00:14:44.500
The part I always forget,

310
00:14:44.500 --> 00:14:49.230
cuz I'm from the Sysco stuff, I always
forget to leave the space out, right?

311
00:14:49.230 --> 00:14:50.960
It does need to be nodebug all one word.

312
00:14:50.960 --> 00:14:52.550
If you put the space in there,
it doesn't work.

313
00:14:52.550 --> 00:14:53.910
So I just turned that off.

314
00:14:53.910 --> 00:14:57.480
But if I do a lookup now for
itpro.tv, it's gonna reach out.

315
00:14:57.480 --> 00:15:01.130
And see how I got can't find itpro.tv,
server failed?

316
00:15:01.130 --> 00:15:01.981
It worked a minute ago.

317
00:15:01.981 --> 00:15:03.820
Why isn't it working now?

318
00:15:03.820 --> 00:15:05.990
Well, because I turned off recursion.

319
00:15:05.990 --> 00:15:07.720
If I do a set debug.

320
00:15:07.720 --> 00:15:11.020
And I redo that look up,
I can look in here and

321
00:15:11.020 --> 00:15:14.638
I can see I got a code that
said server fail, all right?

322
00:15:14.638 --> 00:15:19.943
I ask one question, I sent it there, but
not notice I've got, I want a response.

323
00:15:19.943 --> 00:15:24.480
Recursion is available but
I didn't ask for recursion.

324
00:15:24.480 --> 00:15:28.430
And so it didn't do it, and
as a result I didn't get the answer,

325
00:15:28.430 --> 00:15:29.610
because I blocked it.

326
00:15:29.610 --> 00:15:34.800
If I do a set recurse and turn that
back on, now I can do that lookup.

327
00:15:34.800 --> 00:15:37.090
And it should work this time, there we go.

328
00:15:37.090 --> 00:15:40.910
So it worked, and if I scroll back,
there's that want recursion,

329
00:15:40.910 --> 00:15:43.060
that's the key part right
there that we're changing.

330
00:15:43.060 --> 00:15:45.660
So I'm manipulating the way
the query actually runs.

331
00:15:45.660 --> 00:15:47.230
And that's very powerful.

332
00:15:47.230 --> 00:15:50.583
Because if you're trying to test,
is your SOA working?

333
00:15:50.583 --> 00:15:52.219
You could point to the SOA server,

334
00:15:52.219 --> 00:15:55.323
and you would wanna turn off your
recursion there and make sure you

335
00:15:55.323 --> 00:15:58.336
are getting the authoritative
answer right from that server.

336
00:15:58.336 --> 00:16:00.925
All right, other things we can do here.

337
00:16:00.925 --> 00:16:02.809
Let me turn off some of this
stuff that I've got on.

338
00:16:02.809 --> 00:16:05.764
So I'm gonna do a nodebug and
I'm gonna set recurse back on.

339
00:16:05.764 --> 00:16:11.501
All right, when I did my lookup for
itvpro.tv and I had debug turned on,

340
00:16:11.501 --> 00:16:17.630
you saw where I asked for an a record and
a fora record, IPV4 and IPV6.

341
00:16:17.630 --> 00:16:21.610
When you do a lookup, and
we don't have an IPv6 record for ITProTV.

342
00:16:21.610 --> 00:16:23.854
So let me pick somebody who does,
like Google.

343
00:16:23.854 --> 00:16:27.531
If I do a lookup for Google.com,
right, I get all their addresses.

344
00:16:27.531 --> 00:16:31.660
And notice here's IPv4 addresses and
an IPv6 address.

345
00:16:31.660 --> 00:16:33.420
It looked up both.

346
00:16:33.420 --> 00:16:34.650
But you can manipulate that.

347
00:16:34.650 --> 00:16:37.280
If you look at all the set
commands that we can run,

348
00:16:37.280 --> 00:16:39.590
one of the set commands is type.

349
00:16:39.590 --> 00:16:41.810
And there's actually an old
format which is Query Type.

350
00:16:41.810 --> 00:16:44.250
It's actually the same thing,
just more typing.

351
00:16:44.250 --> 00:16:47.020
So if you type equals you
can tell it exactly what

352
00:16:47.020 --> 00:16:48.730
kind of record you're looking for.

353
00:16:48.730 --> 00:16:54.890
So if I do a set type equals A,
I'm only going to look for the A records.

354
00:16:54.890 --> 00:17:00.659
And now when I do Google dot com I
don't get the IP B six record, right?

355
00:17:00.659 --> 00:17:04.735
Likewise, I could say set type=AAAA.

356
00:17:04.735 --> 00:17:09.060
And now when I query Google,
I only get the IPv6 record, right?

357
00:17:09.060 --> 00:17:10.390
Now I'll be honest with you guys,

358
00:17:10.390 --> 00:17:14.410
I don't do this one very often
because I normally want both., right?

359
00:17:14.410 --> 00:17:16.880
But where I use this are other records.

360
00:17:16.880 --> 00:17:21.570
Hey, I wanna find out who's
the authoritative DNS Server for ITProTV?

361
00:17:22.650 --> 00:17:23.490
I don't know, right?

362
00:17:23.490 --> 00:17:25.192
So if I want to find out,

363
00:17:25.192 --> 00:17:29.203
I can set my type to NS to show
me the name server records.

364
00:17:29.203 --> 00:17:32.894
And let me pull that up for itpro.tv.

365
00:17:32.894 --> 00:17:36.321
All right, so I'll punch that in itpro.tv,
and it's going to reach out and

366
00:17:36.321 --> 00:17:38.150
it's going to find out.

367
00:17:38.150 --> 00:17:41.620
Here is the authorised DNS server
where it's supposed to be and

368
00:17:41.620 --> 00:17:43.320
you'll see ours is hosted
in the m zone web services.

369
00:17:43.320 --> 00:17:46.370
So we've got awsdns server
listed right there.

370
00:17:46.370 --> 00:17:49.010
So if I were to look up
against one these guys,

371
00:17:49.010 --> 00:17:52.490
they could give me an authorated
answer for our domain, right?

372
00:17:52.490 --> 00:17:56.224
Because I changed that type,
these records aren't normally shown to me.

373
00:17:56.224 --> 00:18:01.286
I could also do set type=MX, right?

374
00:18:01.286 --> 00:18:04.800
I want to see the mail
exchange records for itpro.tv.

375
00:18:04.800 --> 00:18:06.680
And so I can punch that in.

376
00:18:06.680 --> 00:18:07.970
And now I can see right there.

377
00:18:07.970 --> 00:18:11.457
There's the
Itpro-tv.mail.protection.outlook.com.

378
00:18:11.457 --> 00:18:12.776
It's in Office 365.

379
00:18:12.776 --> 00:18:17.046
So that's an easy way to spot who's using
Office 365, or Google apps for work or

380
00:18:17.046 --> 00:18:17.970
whatever.

381
00:18:17.970 --> 00:18:20.360
I can see those mail exchanger records.

382
00:18:20.360 --> 00:18:21.980
Right there, okay.

383
00:18:21.980 --> 00:18:25.260
Now my favorite set type command is one

384
00:18:25.260 --> 00:18:27.570
that actually I'm not even sure
if it's in the documentation.

385
00:18:27.570 --> 00:18:28.770
Let's see if it shows up.

386
00:18:28.770 --> 00:18:33.550
But it's set type equals all,
enter or any, any or

387
00:18:33.550 --> 00:18:35.940
all is the same thing,
they get processed the same way.

388
00:18:35.940 --> 00:18:37.320
But we can punch that in.

389
00:18:37.320 --> 00:18:43.235
And so if you do a set type=ALL,
now when I do that lookup for

390
00:18:43.235 --> 00:18:49.150
itpro.tv it's gonna return
everything that it can, okay?

391
00:18:49.150 --> 00:18:51.380
And all and any, they work the same way.

392
00:18:51.380 --> 00:18:54.240
So you can punch in either one,
I did all because that's what I'm used to,

393
00:18:54.240 --> 00:18:55.570
any was in the documentation.

394
00:18:55.570 --> 00:18:58.280
But if I look,
I'm getting the name server records.

395
00:18:58.280 --> 00:19:03.490
I'm getting the MX records,
I'm also getting text records down here.

396
00:19:03.490 --> 00:19:09.530
Which are really handy if you working for
like a sender policy framework SPF,

397
00:19:09.530 --> 00:19:12.700
like you're doing anti spam measures and
your DNS record.

398
00:19:12.700 --> 00:19:17.580
You can come and you can see those text
records and see what is my SPF set to and

399
00:19:17.580 --> 00:19:21.530
you will start to see the approved
email servers For ITPro.TV.

400
00:19:21.530 --> 00:19:24.760
You can really get some
good data right in here.

401
00:19:24.760 --> 00:19:26.200
All just by viewing that domain.

402
00:19:26.200 --> 00:19:29.000
And that's a pretty handy thing to see.

403
00:19:29.000 --> 00:19:34.800
All right, let's see what else do we
have in here that we can tinker with?

404
00:19:34.800 --> 00:19:36.810
Let me show an older command.

405
00:19:36.810 --> 00:19:40.920
This one is not incredibly
useful on public DNS servers.

406
00:19:40.920 --> 00:19:42.630
It's the ls command.

407
00:19:42.630 --> 00:19:45.480
The ls command is the list command, and

408
00:19:45.480 --> 00:19:49.000
what you used to be able to do back in the
day when the Internet was very small was

409
00:19:49.000 --> 00:19:54.440
that you could connect to a DNS server and
you could say ls itpro.tv.

410
00:19:54.440 --> 00:19:58.960
And that would say give me the listing for
the itpro.tv DNS server.

411
00:19:58.960 --> 00:20:03.910
Give me everything you've
got in the DNS file format.

412
00:20:03.910 --> 00:20:08.050
And it would output it on the screen in a
file format that you could save as a text

413
00:20:08.050 --> 00:20:11.380
file and load right into bind or
Windows DNS or whatever.

414
00:20:11.380 --> 00:20:12.590
Now you could host that zone.

415
00:20:12.590 --> 00:20:15.160
What you're effectively doing is
what's called a zone transfer, right?

416
00:20:15.160 --> 00:20:18.010
A zone transfer is when we synchronize
a zone between two DNS servers.

417
00:20:18.010 --> 00:20:19.660
They're using the ls command.

418
00:20:19.660 --> 00:20:22.320
You used to be able to do
something pretty much any domain.

419
00:20:22.320 --> 00:20:24.600
Now when you do it,
you'll get the error restricted, right?

420
00:20:24.600 --> 00:20:27.072
Can't list domain server failed.

421
00:20:27.072 --> 00:20:31.902
So, not useful on a public server, but on
a private server, in your own business if

422
00:20:31.902 --> 00:20:36.456
you've got Microsoft Active Directory,
or Bind running on your own Linux and

423
00:20:36.456 --> 00:20:40.330
Unix servers, you might want to
connect up and do a zone transfer.

424
00:20:40.330 --> 00:20:43.430
Connect and download the whole
zone file to back it up.

425
00:20:43.430 --> 00:20:46.600
And that way if you ever lose the server
you've got a backup on the zone file

426
00:20:46.600 --> 00:20:48.370
right here in this ls command.

427
00:20:48.370 --> 00:20:51.200
And you can do ls for
whatever your domain is, right, so

428
00:20:51.200 --> 00:20:53.800
maybe you have like company.com.

429
00:20:53.800 --> 00:20:56.865
And then you can pipe that into a file, so

430
00:20:56.865 --> 00:21:02.020
you might call it company.com.dns
that's the normal file name.

431
00:21:02.020 --> 00:21:04.441
It's just a text file,
call it whatever you want but

432
00:21:04.441 --> 00:21:07.522
most people do end them with dot-dns and
if you're running bind or

433
00:21:07.522 --> 00:21:10.399
Window DNS they actually look for
a file like that for domain.

434
00:21:10.399 --> 00:21:13.415
And I can dump into a file
copy that to a DNS server and

435
00:21:13.415 --> 00:21:17.188
bring that zone right back up
on a new DNS server very easily.

436
00:21:17.188 --> 00:21:20.770
All right, so on private servers
that works if you are approved for

437
00:21:20.770 --> 00:21:22.500
doing zone transfers.

438
00:21:22.500 --> 00:21:26.340
On public servers, you’re not normally
approved for doing zoned transfers.

439
00:21:26.340 --> 00:21:29.150
You at least have to be listed
as a NS record but most of them

440
00:21:29.150 --> 00:21:32.210
actually require you to put it into
some security profile on the back end.

441
00:21:32.210 --> 00:21:35.770
So that's neat command that's there that

442
00:21:35.770 --> 00:21:40.180
just not you really don't see it
really in use all that often anymore.

443
00:21:40.180 --> 00:21:43.010
Because you've gotta be approved, right?

444
00:21:43.010 --> 00:21:46.460
Security is far different in the world
of DNS today than what it used to be.

445
00:21:46.460 --> 00:21:49.250
>> Don, that's a lot of great information,
in fact now I'm gonna be using that set

446
00:21:49.250 --> 00:21:50.810
command now that I know
it a little bit better.

447
00:21:50.810 --> 00:21:54.030
It does look like we're gonna wrap
this one up soon, but before we do,

448
00:21:54.030 --> 00:21:56.790
do you got any additional
words on using NS lookup?

449
00:21:56.790 --> 00:21:58.280
Any tips or tricks?

450
00:21:58.280 --> 00:22:00.810
>> There are more commands in there,
and you probably notice like when I did

451
00:22:00.810 --> 00:22:03.400
the question mark there were
a handful like setting the class and

452
00:22:03.400 --> 00:22:05.030
setting route and so on.

453
00:22:05.030 --> 00:22:09.746
Those are useful in very,
very few scenarios.

454
00:22:09.746 --> 00:22:10.938
Class is pretty much useless.

455
00:22:10.938 --> 00:22:13.060
There's really only one class these days.

456
00:22:13.060 --> 00:22:14.540
The IN, or the internet class.

457
00:22:14.540 --> 00:22:17.777
The other ones are like the chaos class,
the class, the test class.

458
00:22:17.777 --> 00:22:19.890
Those are all way back in
the early days of DNS, and

459
00:22:19.890 --> 00:22:21.790
they aren't really used anymore.

460
00:22:21.790 --> 00:22:26.380
Other ones like manipulating how
the internet transfers work,

461
00:22:26.380 --> 00:22:28.730
again there's really only
one way in use anymore, so

462
00:22:28.730 --> 00:22:31.160
there's not really a reason
to override those.

463
00:22:31.160 --> 00:22:34.970
Root can be kind of handy, if you're
overriding the root hint servers on

464
00:22:34.970 --> 00:22:38.320
the internet, if you're not using those,
you can connect to any server and

465
00:22:38.320 --> 00:22:40.190
use the set root command.

466
00:22:40.190 --> 00:22:43.560
To flag it as the root and
you won't use root hints anymore.

467
00:22:43.560 --> 00:22:45.610
Everything will go
against that one server.

468
00:22:45.610 --> 00:22:49.730
Not something I've ever had to use
in production, but it is there.

469
00:22:49.730 --> 00:22:53.500
So the commands that I
didn't show are ones that

470
00:22:53.500 --> 00:22:55.820
just we're not really gonna use that much.

471
00:22:55.820 --> 00:22:58.480
There's the search list command,
where you can create

472
00:22:58.480 --> 00:23:01.670
a suffix search list if you want,
right there inside of NSLookup.

473
00:23:01.670 --> 00:23:03.470
We've usually already got
that defined on our systems,

474
00:23:03.470 --> 00:23:05.050
we don't necessarily need it there.

475
00:23:05.050 --> 00:23:08.530
And then timeouts and retries.

476
00:23:08.530 --> 00:23:11.380
You can override the timeout time and
the retry time.

477
00:23:11.380 --> 00:23:15.740
They're the amount of retries,
and the interval of the timeout,

478
00:23:15.740 --> 00:23:18.770
to use the right terminology
to kinda manipulate those.

479
00:23:18.770 --> 00:23:20.960
Again, less common use scenario.

480
00:23:20.960 --> 00:23:24.576
What we saw through the whole beginning of
this is really kinda the important meat

481
00:23:24.576 --> 00:23:25.809
and potatoes of NS hookup.

482
00:23:25.809 --> 00:23:28.136
>> Well, Don, that's a wealth of
information and we appreciate it.

483
00:23:28.136 --> 00:23:32.108
We appreciate the viewers, so we're gonna
go ahead and sign out here at ITProTV.

484
00:23:32.108 --> 00:23:33.619
I've been your host, Wes Brian.

485
00:23:33.619 --> 00:23:34.493
>> And I'm Don Pozet.

486
00:23:34.493 --> 00:23:36.747
>> And we'll see you next time.

487
00:23:36.747 --> 00:23:42.694
[MUSIC]

488
00:23:42.694 --> 00:23:46.127
>> Thank you for watching, IT Pro TV.

489
00:23:46.127 --> 00:23:48.960
[BLANK AUDIO]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explain how to use the Domain Internet Groper utility more commonly known as dig. They explain some of the command line arguments that can be utilized with dig.
episodes.title: dig

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don take a look a a couple of powerful DNS utilities to help keep your DNS infrastructure running efficiently. They explain how to do DNS zone debugging with dnswalk. They will also look at using dnsrecon to analyze and enumerate a DNS zone.
episodes.title: dnswalk and dnsrecon

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don take a look at DNS the various records that are created and stored on the server. They explain records like host A and AAAA records, CNAME and PTR records
episodes.title: Host Records

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don dive into the world of service locator records commonly called SRV records. They the purpose of the records and how they help us locate services inside and outside of our networks1
episodes.title: SRV Records

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore using and configuring mail exchanger records also known as MX records. They talk about some of the components of the MX record type such as domain name, time-to-live or TTL as well as the priority or preference that can be set when using multiple servers are used.
episodes.title: Configuring MX Records

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore the world of Sender Policy Framework or SPF records commonly called SPF records. They explain topics like the SPF record format. qualifiers and different mechanisms that can be used. They will also dive into the best practices that should be employed when using SPF records.
episodes.title: Configuring SPF Records

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don discuss some of the important considerations when purchasing a domain for your company. They explain registrars as well as giving examples of popular domain registrars. They will also examine the records associated with a domain purchase such as registration, owner, administrator, and billing records. They also demonstrate using the ICANN WHOIS Lookup to verify the domain information and records.
episodes.title: Purchasing a Domain

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explain the task of changing the DNS server or servers that are authoritative for a domain. They demonstrate the process as well as discuss DNS NS records.
episodes.title: Changing Name Servers

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate the process of transferring domains between registrars. They explain the security requirements such as “Transfer Locks” and the extensible provisioning protocol or EPP commonly called an authentication code. They also look at the standards bodies that oversee domain like the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) and the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN)
episodes.title: Transferring a Domain

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don start the journey through securing DNS Zones on an NSD server. In the first part they will demonstrate getting the prerequisites installed and configured
episodes.title: Configuring DNSSEC with NSD

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their journey through securing DNS zones on an NSD server. They look at creating the keys for the zone and explain the records that are added when using DNSSEC and configuring the registrar to use DNSSEC.
episodes.title: Configuring DNSSEC with NSD Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don talk about the not to common DNS server implementation used in technologies like root hint servers and DNSSEC called NSD. They discuss the installation of NSD within a Linux system, considerations and demonstrate the process.
episodes.title: Installing NSD

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don talk about the not to common DNS server implementation used in technologies like root hint servers and DNSSEC called NSD. They discuss the step-by-step process of configuring the DNS zone in NSD as well as demonstrate the SOA record configuration, BIND syntax of the zone file an
episodes.title: Configuring Zones in NSD

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don dive into NSD zone replication and concepts such as master (primary) and slave (secondary) zone. They demonstrate the process of configuring DNS zone replication on NSD
episodes.title: Configuring Replication in NSD

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their dive into NSD zone replication and concepts such as master (primary) and slave (secondary) zone. They demonstrate the process of configuring DNS zone replication on NSD
episodes.title: Configuring Replication in NSD Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don examine how to get a DNS server up and running on an installation of Windows Server. They look at the basic installation and talk about DNS concepts.
episodes.title: Installing Microsoft DNS

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don have already brought the DNS server online and are now ready to begin creating the DNS database. They look at DNS zones and zone types as well as demonstrate the process of configuring DNS zones in Windows Server.
episodes.title: Configuring Zones in Microsoft DNS

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue the process of DNS configuration on Windows Server. They will tackle DNS zone replication this time, while discussing the purpose, benefits as well as a demonstration in the configuration process.
episodes.title: Configuring Replication in Microsoft DNS

episodes.description: In this episode Don and Cherokee discuss and demonstrate how to install a BIND (Berkley Internet Naming Domain) DNS Server. BIND is an older but very important reference DNS program which is available for a variety of operating  systems. We see how to edit the configuration file, start the service and allow BIND thru the firewalld.
episodes.title: Installing BIND

episodes.description: Once BIND is installed you will need to configure zones if you do not intend to use it solely as a DNS cache server. You will see how to create separate zone files and link back into the configuration file to reference the zones that have been generated. Don demonstrates how to create a variety of records in the forward lookup zone.
episodes.title: Configuring Zones and Records

episodes.description: This episode is a continuation of learning how to configure zones and records. In the previous episodes you saw how to create forward lookup zones and here you will learn how to create a reverse lookup zone.
episodes.title: Configuring Zones and Records Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate replication of the DNS database. They show how to set up the master DNS server as well as setting up the slave DNS server to receive the DNS zone database.
episodes.title: Configuring Replication

episodes.description: In this episode you will see how to install another DNS program called Unbound. Unbound is a newer, faster but not as flexible alternative which is usually used in conjunction with another system such as BIND. You will learn how to edit the configuration file to customize your server, enable logging, enable access controls, verify configuration files, start the service and allow Unbound through the firewalld.
episodes.title: Installing Unbound

episodes.description: After installing Unbound you will learn how to create override lookup values to customize your environment. You will see how Unbound functions faster, yet is limited in some ways such as not properly referencing a CNAME record.
episodes.title: Configuring Zones and Records

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explain how to reduce ads being delivered to your end-users with Unbound. They show you how to configure the DNS server such obtaining Gavin’s script, executing it and verifying the presences of the file as well as testing the ad blocking capabilities.
episodes.title: Blocking Ads with Unbound

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don show the viewers how to take advantage of the benefits of bringing Unbound into combination with BIND. They demonstrate how to set up Unbound to receive and forward DNS queries to a BIND server as well as combine both Unbound and BIND on a single server.
episodes.title: Using Unbound with BIND

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don show the viewers how to take advantage of the benefits of bringing Unbound into combination with NSD. They demonstrate how to set up Unbound to receive and forward DNS queries to a NSD server on the same physical machine.
episodes.title: Using Unbound with NSD
